pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

It is my first PR to mathlib4 so comments on how to improve on the formalisation are welcome.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Hi! I just randomly stumbled over your PR and saw it hasn't been looked at in a while: one reason might be that there's currently a merge conflict - this means it won't show up in the list of reviewable PRs. Cheers!
(I'm not quite working in this area, hence can't review this well myself.)
I have resolved the merge conflict. Thanks for the tip.
No worries! Thanks for the comments. I'll try to add back the `align` soon!
@Ruben-VandeVelde Sorry I got a little busy with life! Thanks for suggesting and making the changes!
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

Thanks!

bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9115738888/job/25062751813)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9115883916/job/25063225415)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9115883916/job/25063224949)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9115883916/job/25063226209)
Mainly stylistic remarks, I also don't know anything about the mathematics, but generally it looks good.
maintainer merge

Thanks! And welcome to contributing to Mathlib! We're happy to have you here. I have left a few comments. The golfs are probably useless because of the other changes I'm recommending, but I thought I would show you how I might clean things up a bit.

The main issue is that I think your definition of `succ_diff_bounded` is causing some pain. New definitions are always the hardest thing to get right. I think I left you a plan for how to deal with that.
Mainly stylistic remarks, I also don't know anything about the mathematics, but generally it looks good.

I have a few more comments. One comment may need more attention (which I'll ask about on zulip); the others are small bits of polish: we can make your code even shorter.
I remember getting lots of these in my first PRs - but it's also an opportunity to learn more, for future Lean code you may want to write.
Apologies for the delay here. I also have a number of minor comments, but overall, it looks good to me.
maintainer merge

No need to use `C : ℝ≥0∞` if you are just going to assume `C ≠ ∞`, instead just use `ℝ≥0`. Also, with this notation notice that we can combine the existence of `C` with the assumption that it is positive.
```suggestion
  ∃ C > (0 : ℝ≥0), ∀ (n : ℕ), (u (n + 2) - u (n + 1)) ≤ C * (u (n + 1) - u n)
```
However, I think ultimately I would just pass `C` as an argument to `succ_diff_bounded` like we do with [LipschitzOnWith](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/EMetricSpace/Lipschitz.html#LipschitzOnWith) instead of hiding it behind the existential. That way we can access the `C`.

Finally, I suspect that a lot of the pain you are dealing with is a result of coercions, some of which are caused by this definition. If you choose `C : ℕ` instead, it may make your life significantly easier.

Thanks for the detailed review! I chose to use `∃ (C : ℝ≥0∞) (_ : C ≠ ∞) (_ : C > 0)` because I am getting some coercions errors that I do not really know how to deal with. I tried changing the definition to
```
def succ_diff_bounded (C : ℕ+) (u : ℕ → ℕ) : Prop :=
  ∀ (n : ℕ), (u (n + 2) - u (n + 1)) ≤ C * (u (n + 1) - u n)
```
which gives me a coercion error
```
application type mismatch
  mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (h_succ_diff k)
argument
  h_succ_diff k
has type
  u (k + 2) - u (k + 1) ≤ ↑C * (u (k + 1) - u k) : Prop
but is expected to have type
  ↑(u (k + 2)) - ↑(u (k + 1)) ≤ ↑↑C * (↑(u (k + 1)) - ↑(u k)) : Prop

```
 that I am not sure where to start to resolve.

A more fundamental issue that I have doubts about is that I defined f as `{f : ℕ → ℝ≥0∞}` in the namespace `Finset` instead of the original
```
variable {M : Type*} [OrderedAddCommMonoid M] {f : ℕ → M}
```
Also, if I defined it as `{f : ℕ → ℝ≥0}`, there will be some type mismatch error when doing
```
  refine' iSup_le fun n => (Finset.le_sum_schlomilch hf h_pos hu n).trans (add_le_add_left _ _)
```
in `ENNReal.le_tsum_schlomilch`. I will work on the rest of the comments!
Minor remark: with the current naming convention, you should use `CamelCase` name for this definition.

I know this file didn't phrase things in terms of [Monotone](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Monotone/Basic.html#Monotone), [StrictMono](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Monotone/Basic.html#StrictMono), [MonotoneOn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Monotone/Basic.html#MonotoneOn) or [StrictMonoOn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Monotone/Basic.html#StrictMonoOn), but it probably would be nice if it did. I encourage you to rephrase this file in that language.

If you use those then this lemma is just [StrictMono.tendsto_atTop](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Filter/AtTopBot.html#StrictMono.tendsto_atTop).
And with the above, this is just [StrictMono.monotone](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Monotone/Basic.html#StrictMono.monotone)

a short golf. Note also how you can pass parameters to `have` just like declarations (i.e., the `(k : ℕ)`) so you don't have to write `intro k`.
```suggestion
  have (k : ℕ) : (u (k + 1) - (u k : ℝ)) = ((u (k + 1) : ℝ≥0) - (u k : ℝ≥0) : ℝ≥0) := by
    have := Nat.cast_le (α := ℝ≥0).mpr <| (strict_mono (zero_le k) k.lt_succ_self).le
    simp [NNReal.coe_sub this]
```

reasoning in reverse is sometimes quite helpful. Maybe you haven't learned some of these tactics yet:
```suggestion
    pow_lt_pow (Nat.lt_succ_self 1) hmn
  have h_succ_diff : succ_diff_bounded (fun n => 2 ^ n) :=
    ⟨2, by norm_num, by norm_num, by simp [pow_succ, two_mul]⟩
  convert summable_schlomilch_iff_of_nonneg h_nonneg h_mono h_pos strict_mono h_succ_diff
  simp only [Nat.cast_pow, Nat.cast_ofNat]
  simp [pow_succ, two_mul]
```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ∑' k , f k ≤ ∑ k in range (u 0), f k + ∑' k : ℕ, (u (k + 1) - u k) * f (u k) := by ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ∑' k , f k ≤ ∑ k in range (u 0), f k + ∑' k : ℕ, (u (k + 1) - u k) * f (u k) := by ```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
  ∀ n : ℕ, u (n + 2) - u (n + 1) ≤ C • (u (n + 1) - u n)
```

```suggestion
    (h_nonneg : ∀ n, 0 ≤ f n) (hu : Monotone u) (h_succ_diff : SuccDiffBounded C u) (n : ℕ) :
```
`\leq` in VSCode

```suggestion
  gcongr
```

```suggestion
    refine this.trans (nsmul_le_nsmul_right ?_ _)
```
Generally, `refine'` is discouraged, the better alternatives are `apply` (if you don't want to use tons of trailing underscores) and `refine` (where you have to specify with `?_` which goals are still left)
Is it for performance reasons that `refine'` is discouraged?

I believe it's not because of performance: basically, they are very similar; `refine` is clearer (as it distinguishes so-called holes (`_` in the code) which you want Lean to fill from `?_` which you want Lean to turn into new goals for you.
This [thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/refine.20vs.20refine') on zulip goes into many details. In particular, there are about eight thousand calls of `refine'` left, so these will not be all rewritten manually.

```suggestion
    replace h_nonneg : ∀ n, 0 ≤ (f n : ℝ≥0∞) := fun n =>
      ENNReal.coe_le_coe.2 (h_nonneg n)
    obtain hC := tsum_schlomilch_le hf h_pos h_nonneg hu_strict h_succ_diff
    have C_nonzero : C ≠ 0 := ne_of_gt hCpos
    have : (↑(u 1) - ↑(u 0)) * ↑(f (u 0)) + ↑C * ∑' (k : ℕ), ↑(f k) = ∞ := by exact eq_top_mono hC h
    simpa [add_eq_top, mul_ne_top, mul_eq_top, C_nonzero]
```
since `ENNReal` is opened I don't see why we should qualify the names (`coe_le_coe` needs to be qualified however)

```suggestion
  have h_pos : ∀ (n : ℕ), 0 < 2 ^ n := (pow_pos zero_lt_two ·)
  have hu_strict : StrictMono (2 ^ ·) := fun m n hm =>
```
Simple `fun`s can often be replaced with `\.` notation

```suggestion
  have h_succ_diff : SuccDiffBounded 2 (2 ^ ·) := by
```

You're removing #align-ed declarations: as a heads-up, I think this is undesirable.
(These were created during porting mathlib from Lean 3 to Lean 4. As I understand it, the current plan is to remove them at some point - but it's not clear when that will be.)

I'm not sure what the best fix is: keep the old declarations as a special case? (Sometimes, that's worth it anyway, if the special case is the version many people need.) Point the align to the new version?

 I'll ask on zulip.

Thanks for the thread on Zulip. I have added back the theorems `summable_condensed_iff` and `summable_condensed_iff_of_nonneg` since they are more frequently used. ~~I am not sure if we should keep the old declarations for the rest of the theorems since they are really lemmas for the final two theorems.~~

All the `#align`(s) should be back.

Optional, but given you're rewriting the code anyway: you may also replace this refine' by e.g. `refine`.

(Rule of thumb: replace `refine'` by `refine`; Lean should error "can't synthesize missing placeholder", underlining an "_". Replace these by `?_`, possibly repeat this. If Lean still complains, keep it at `refine'`. If you get stuck, feel free to ask for help - #new members on zulip is open for *all* kinds of questions, there are no dumb questions! - or don't pursue this change.)

You can simplify this a bit further:
- an `apply` on the last line usually be converted to `exact`, an usually this is desirable
(There are exceptions to this rule, but "always use exact" is a good first rule of thumb.)
- `by exact` can be omitted --- then you just give a proof term, no need to use tactic mode
- you can use dot notation: since `hu_strict` has type `StrictMono` and you're applying a lemma from that namespace, you can also write this as `hu_strict.monotone`.
Altogether, you obtain `have hu : Monotone u := hu_strict.monotone`.

- at this point, you can consider "inlining" this `have`, i.e. replacing it by its proof whenever you use it.
My rule of thumb is that if a proof term is long or you use it at least three times, you should probably extract it. If it's short and you use it once (like here), I would inline.
This can be `exact` again.
This `have` you can also simplify, similar to the one above.
You can also simplify this have, using "nested have's".
I must have missed this in the documentation. Can you explain what you mean by nested have's?

Sure: your `have` can depend on a parameter, e.g. a natural number n: this way, you can avoid the `intro` as first proof step. You have this on line 122 of that file already.
More explicitly, you could write this as
```suggestion
  have h_pos (n : ℕ) : 0 < 2 ^ n := pow_pos zero_lt_two n
Here's a "by exact" you can also remove.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion for a strictly increasing `u : ℕ → ℕ` with ratio of successive differences bounded and an ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (∑ k in range n, 2 ^ k • f (2 ^ (k + 1))) ≤ ∑ k in Ico 2 (2 ^ n + 1), f k := by ```

The line break ends up in a bit of a strange place here; I suggest
```suggestion
    (hu : Monotone u) (n : ℕ) :
    (∑ k in range (u n), f k) ≤
      ∑ k in range (u 0), f k + ∑ k in range n, (u (k + 1) - u k) • f (u k) := by
```

Also here:
```suggestion
    (hu : Monotone u) (n : ℕ) :
    (∑ k in range n, (u (k + 1) - u k) • f (u (k + 1))) ≤ ∑ k in Ico (u 0 + 1) (u n + 1), f k := by
```
I'd just use `hu_strict.monotone` in the one place you need it below. Also, maybe rename `hu_strict` to `hu`
I think we prefer keeping this empty line; also below
I think at least one of the `ℝ≥0∞` type annotations is unnecessary; can you take a look?
This appears to be true for `hu : Monotone u`
I'm always wary of up-arrows without a type annotation. Do they actually do something? If so, try writing this with the target type
Ditto. Also, instead of `ne_top_of_lt` I guess you can use `(sum_lt_top ..).ne'`

```suggestion
  have hu_strict : StrictMono (2 ^ ·) := pow_right_strictMono one_lt_two
```

```suggestion
  convert summable_schlomilch_iff hf h_pos hu_strict two_ne_zero h_succ_diff
```

```suggestion
#align nnreal.summable_condensed_iff NNReal.summable_condensed_iff

end NNReal
```
Please put this comment back on the theorem below

```suggestion
  lift f to ℕ → ℝ≥0 using h_nonneg
```
Same comments as above

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Analysis/PSeries): add Schlömilch's generalization of the Cauchy condensation test

nodes.body:
Thanks! And welcome to contributing to Mathlib! We're happy to have you here. I have left a few comments. The golfs are probably useless because of the other changes I'm recommending, but I thought I would show you how I might clean things up a bit.

The main issue is that I think your definition of `succ_diff_bounded` is causing some pain. New definitions are always the hardest thing to get right. I think I left you a plan for how to deal with that.

Hi! I just randomly stumbled over your PR and saw it hasn't been looked at in a while: one reason might be that there's currently a merge conflict - this means it won't show up in the list of reviewable PRs. Cheers!
(I'm not quite working in this area, hence can't review this well myself.)
I have resolved the merge conflict. Thanks for the tip.
Mainly stylistic remarks, I also don't know anything about the mathematics, but generally it looks good.

I have a few more comments. One comment may need more attention (which I'll ask about on zulip); the others are small bits of polish: we can make your code even shorter.
I remember getting lots of these in my first PRs - but it's also an opportunity to learn more, for future Lean code you may want to write.
No worries! Thanks for the comments. I'll try to add back the `align` soon!
Apologies for the delay here. I also have a number of minor comments, but overall, it looks good to me.
@Ruben-VandeVelde Sorry I got a little busy with life! Thanks for suggesting and making the changes!
